Award.AwardTitle: Elementary Particle Physics with Collider Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund work on the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN). During the three-year period of this project CMS will be collecting data from proton-proton collisions at the highest collision energy ever attained in a man-made accelerator, 13 trillion electron-volts. Using its prior CMS data analysis experience, the KU group intends to use this new data to search for new phenomena beyond the Standard Model that describes the elementary particles known to date and explore the subatomic forces that interact with these elementary particles. The group also does significant work on public outreach efforts. Its most unique outreach project is Quarked!TM Adventures in the Subatomic Universe, a multimedia project aimed at students age seven and up. Content from this project can be found online at www.quarked.org. This grant will also provide for the training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in the essential skills of the field. The group also has a strong record of success in mentoring undergraduate researchers. The group's broader educational mission includes communicating about science with the general public through public talks and other means.

The intellectual merit of the research program comes from increasing our basic understanding of matter and energy at the smallest experimentally accessible distance scales. The discovery at the LHC of the Higgs boson with a mass around 125 GeV opened up fascinating opportunities for investigations at the current LHC energy of 13 TeV. The KU data analysis efforts will focus on exploiting the Higgs boson as a tool for discovery. The group is currently using a data set that was collected in 2015 to search for electroweak production of a vector-like quark decaying to a top quark and a Higgs boson using boosted topologies in the all-hadronic final state. Extensions of this work, funded by this award, will explore data taken in 2016 and thereafter and include other production and decay modes of vector-like quarks.

One of the two X-ray test centers for the Phase I forward pixel detector for the phase-I upgrade of the CMS detector is located at KU. Here, the group tests the modules to assure that the bump bonding was successful, the energy calibration works, and that the module is operational under high rates. KU also hosts a full electronics test chain system with a goal to assure that the system works and that the bit error rate is low for the full system. Once the Phase I FPIX detector is shipped to CERN, this group has committed to help commission the system there.

For the pixel tracker for the planned High Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC) upgrade, the U.S. groups are committed to building the forward pixel system. This system will extend track reconstruction to high pseudo rapidity (up to 4.0) and will ensure good missing energy resolution that plays a critical role in many searches for new physics. The KU group is involved in Monte Carlo studies for the design of the HL-LHC forward pixel detector and is working with groups from the U. Nebraska-Lincoln and Paul Scherrer Institute on studies of small pixels. KU plans to contribute to the electronics and module testing design and construction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF grant 1607262 supported the activities of the University of Kansas (KU) experimental particle physics group from September 1, 2016 until March 31, 2020. About 80% of the funds went to salary support for the group, which includes three faculty members, three postdoctoral researchers, three graduate students, and over a dozen undergraduate students. Travel and supply costs accounted for the rest of the funds.

             The development of the next generation of scientists is perhaps the most important outcome of our work. We provided opportunities for students to gain skills in data analysis, particle detector technology, software development, report writing, and oral presentation. The faculty mentored three postdoctoral researchers, one of whom now has a faculty position in Europe. (The other two are still working with our group.) Three graduate students completed their Masters degrees, achieved candidacy for the Ph.D, and are now working to complete their Ph.D. dissertations. Over a dozen undergraduate students worked with our group. Our outstanding group of undergraduates won recognition, including three national scholarships (two Astronaut Scholarships and one Goldwater Scholarship). One student went on to earn an NSF Fellowship for her graduate work in physics.

               The intellectual merit of the group?s science comes from the potential of our work in the field of particle physics to provide a greater understanding of matter and energy at the smallest distance scales. KU belongs to a collaboration that operates a multipurpose experiment at the forefront of research in this field -- the CMS experiment at CERN's Large Hadron Collider (LHC).

              During this time period, CMS took data from proton-proton collisions at a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV, the highest collision energy ever achieved. Data were taken at this energy starting in 2015 and continuing through the end of 2018. The LHC is now in the middle of a three-year shutdown period. While the experiment was running, KU personnel contributed to the day-to-day operations of the detector and helped to study its performance. Our group?s main responsibility was for the innermost part of the CMS detector, which tracks the paths of charged particles.

             The KU group analyzed the 2015-2018 data, mainly focused on exploiting the Higgs boson as a tool for discovery. The Higgs boson was first discovered in 2012 by the CMS and ATLAS experiments. This unique particle can now be used to search for additional physics phenomena. The group studied the Higgs boson itself, looking for particular decay channels and looking for events in which two Higgs bosons rather than just one are produced. The group also studied our ability to measure the dependence of the Higgs mass on its momentum. (Theoretically, its mass could vary noticeably with the energy scale.) We also searched for new particles that could decay into Higgs bosons. There are six known quarks, but some theories predict additional heavier quarks, such as the proposed T, which can decay into a top quark and a Higgs boson. The KU group used several strategies to try to find the T particles. None were found, but useful knowledge was gained and limits were placed on the possibility of its production. Results from each of these studies were published in leading peer-reviewed physics journals and/or were presented at conferences.

          After the above-described studies the group turned its attention to searches for supersymmetric phenomena that result in leptons and missing energy in the final state. Supersymmetry is one of the best motivated models for new physics and KU is using new techniques to gain sensitivity to previously neglected experimental signatures with an emphasis on sequences of decays of particles with similar masses.

          The group also is working on the development of future experiments. The high luminosity LHC, scheduled to begin operation in 2026, would produce ten times the data of the current LHC. For the HL-LHC, KU is working on flexible, low-mass cables capable of carrying fast electronic signals at 1.28 Gbps. The international linear collider would provide complementary physics from electron-positron collisions. Such a machine would be well suited for a precise exploration of the properties of the Higgs. KU is developing detector concepts and studying the physics potential of such a machine.

              The broader impacts of KU?s work were also considerable. In addition to the training received by graduate, undergraduate and postdoctoral students, we did important outreach work. The Quarked!TM project is designed to get children excited about science, and modern physics in particular. A website (www.quarked.org) was launched in February 2006, and is being continuously enhanced with new online content, educational games and phone apps. Also, KU has been part of QuarkNet, a nationwide project to introduce particle physics into the high school classroom, since 2001. Each summer the KU center runs a workshop for area high school physics teachers with recent topics being dark matter, particle detectors and computational physics.
